attributes.action: Return privatised gas, electric and water to public ownership
attributes.background: To safeguard the integrity of the UK's energy infrastructure, and to operate as non-profit organisations, in order to keep costs to UK businesses and citizens as low as possible, all privatised UK energy and water companies should be returned to public ownership.

departments.name: Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy

attributes.action: Pass a law that prevents the use of standing charges by utility companies
attributes.background: Utility companies are allowed to impose standing charges on customers. These charges are regressive and affect customers who use less energy disproportionally. We believe these charges are unethical, and should be banned.
attributes.additional_details:
When imposing a tax on society the Government rightly considers whether a tax is regressive. Absolute fairness is difficult to achieve but generally the tax system is based around equity where possible. This regard to fairness should apply to standing charges.

The Government, through Parliament, legislate in many areas to ensure that companies attain standards which are held to be acceptable. For example, in regard to public health or safety. We believe action is needed to abolish standing charges.

departments.name: Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy

attributes.action: Bring forward the April 2023 State Pension increase
attributes.background: In view of the cost of living crisis and energy price hikes affecting pensioners, the Government should bring forward the April 2023 pension increase to November of this year in order to partly alleviate next winter's energy costs.
attributes.additional_details:
Increases in state pensions take effect in April but are based on average earnings from the preceding May to July, or inflation for the year ending the previous September.
 
Due to the massive increase in energy costs plus cost of living increases, the Government must bring forward the annual increase in the State Pension to November of this year. Such a move should help to lessen the severe impact of energy costs in particular. If nothing is done to help pensioners, some may not survive through the winter.

departments.name: Department for Work and Pensions

attributes.action: Address the Energy, Climate and Environment crisis by investing in Renewables
attributes.background:
It's a no-brainer. This is a crisis the Government must address by the cheapest, quickest, most environmentally friendly, safest, and most job-creative means. 

Promote and increase Government investment in renewables.
attributes.additional_details:
Fossil fuels are ruining the climate and environment. Nuclear is unsafe.

Home-grown renewable energy and insulating our buildings so we don't lose the heat we produce will create more jobs, be cheaper and be quicker in reducing energy prices and global warming.
We ask the Government to think of the good of our country, our global environment and its people.
 
Increase Government investment in:
- Underwater turbines to harness tidal flows and estuary currents
- Wind farms
- Solar panels.
- Battery technology to store energy.
- Insulation of buildings.

Action, not words, are needed.

departments.name: Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy

attributes.action: Remove 5% VAT rate on gas and electric bills
attributes.background: Surely the general population would agree that one of the answers to the energy/living costs rising should be to stop charging a 5% VAT rate on our energy bills. Gas and Electricity are a necessity in the modern world. We would struggle to live without them especially the vulnerable.
attributes.additional_details:
Everything goes up in price every year to meet inflation and it doesn’t make any difference when we earn more money in our wages it never will until we see taxes being reduced not increases of an hourly rate (£ph) we know of other taxes they include
Council tax, income tax, national insurance, inheritance tax, stamp duty, vehicle excise duty (road tax), capital gains tax, corporate tax, consumption tax, fuel tax, etc. It’s clear to see that there are other ways of getting money from the public.

departments.name: HM Treasury

attributes.action: Work with Ofgem to increase use of voltage optimisation across UK power networks
attributes.background: The UK electricity Distribution Network operators are deliberately keeping the voltage high. The existing OFGEM regulations have no incentive for them to change behaviour. The Government should consider changing the voltage limits and introducing incentives which drive optimisation.
attributes.additional_details: Electricity network operators deliberately keep customer volts high. The regulations only incentivise a reduction in the number/duration of interruptions to supply. Quality of delivered electricity is ignored. This causes wasted energy, high bills, and excessive CO2 emissions. Now smart meters send live voltage readings to data centres and this has confirmed that the problem is universal. One regional network company has accepted the challenge to optimise the voltage by developing an innovative real time automatic voltage control system to keep the voltage lower for the benefit of customers and the environment. The forthcoming regulatory review should include mechanisms which incentivise voltage optimisation across the whole nation.

departments.name: Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy

attributes.action: Cut VAT on domestic electricity to zero
attributes.background: Regarding the 5% VAT on domestic energy consumption, Boris Johnson said in May 2016: "When we Vote Leave, we will be able to scrap this unfair and damaging tax."
attributes.additional_details:
I want the Government to take advantage of this opportunity and reduce VAT on domestic electricity to zero.
 
Ofgem will be increasing the energy price cap substantially in October which may lead to rocketing bills that will, as always, affect those on lower incomes disproportionately.
 
Regarding climate change, we are told that electricity is the future. Cutting VAT on electricity to zero could help mitigate the misery of increased bills as winter sets in and support the move away from reliance on fossil fuels.

departments.name: HM Treasury

attributes.action: Repeal the Climate Change Act 2008
attributes.background: We believe the Act deters the UK energy market from investing in medium and long term hydrocarbon based energy solutions. Until the UK has non hydrocarbon energy security there should not be any legislation or legislative duty targeting carbon usage.
attributes.additional_details: We believe the current policy has prematurely curtailed gas investment, exacerbating the impact of international prices and the actions of unstable and dangerous regimes on the UK. This has contributed to massive price rises, leading to increased fuel poverty. We believe it has also greatly reduced the competitiveness of British businesses and reduced the freedom of manoeuvre for UK government responding to Russia.

departments.name: Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy

attributes.action: Remove VAT on Energy Efficiency Measures To Help Meet 2050 Emissions Target
attributes.background: Taxing people who voluntarily choose to upgrade the energy efficiency of their home goes against the government’s 2050 zero carbon target. Particularly as people building new homes that will ultimately add carbon emissions pay no VAT at all.
attributes.additional_details: Government signed the 2050 Net Zero emissions commitment into law in 2019 and that legislation has since been cited in the decision to prevent a third runway at Heathrow. While VAT on measures such as insulation and heat pumps has been reduced to 5%, it remains at 20% for items like LED lighting and Heat Recovery Ventilation, both of which are essential for a low carbon home. Zero-rating energy saving technologies would stimulate growth in the low carbon economy at a critical time for the UK.

departments.name: Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy

attributes.action: Introduce grants for home battery storage systems
attributes.background: Roll out a grant for home battery storage systems to help reduce the reliance on foreign energy supplies such as gas from Russia, by enabling households to store electricity generated renewably, including domestic solar generation.
attributes.additional_details:
This could also reduce C02 output helping towards Government C02 targets.

Our reliance on foreign fuels such as gas and oil, has been driving up household energy costs and this will become more of an issue with the current war in Ukraine, and deteriorating relations with Russia.

departments.name: Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy

attributes.action: Make helmets a legal requirement for all self-propelled vehicles
attributes.background: I want you to make helmets a compulsory requirement, on any form of transport that is powered by human energy, such as bikes. As I like many others have suffered a head trauma following a bike accident.
attributes.additional_details: I would like to make this change so other families don't have to go through the same heart break, mine has been through. There is much debate about whether helmets should be compulsory, but studies have found that they can reduce head injury and brain trauma by well over 50%. Individuals who do not wear a helmet should be fined.

departments.name: Department for Transport

attributes.action: Join the Beyond Oil and Gas Alliance and commit to its end date for fossil fuels
attributes.background: We are asking the government to join the Beyond Oil and Gas Alliance (spearheaded by Denmark and Costa Rica), commit to its end date by starting the decommissioning processes for extant fossil fuel extraction projects and power stations, and preventing licences for new projects.
attributes.additional_details: The climate crisis is a huge threat to life as we know it. To combat this, the government must transition to renewable energy as fast as possible. Now is the time for rapid, decisive action, not empty rhetoric. The Government must have more ambition in safeguarding the future of its people.

departments.name: Foreign, Commonwealth & Development Office

attributes.action: Subsidise energy prices to offset any increase in the energy price cap
attributes.background: When changes to the energy price cap are implemented in April 2022, the Government should introduce subsidies so that consumers continue to pay prices at current rates.

departments.name: Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy

attributes.action: Make the Warm Home Discount Scheme Accessible Again to the Most Vulnerable
attributes.background: Remove the energy banding and property size criteria. It is impossible to meet especially in light that so many were forced to down size as a result of the bedroom tax.
attributes.additional_details:
The new criteria for Warm Home Discount means it’s almost impossible for anyone to get the support they need if not in the pension guarantee.

The government must remove the impossible criteria and give back vital to support to the most vulnerable, disabled and sick.

Many sick, disabled and vulnerable people are more likely to have higher energy needs and be at home. As well as any medical equipment running costs. 

The new criteria is out of reach now for the majority. It must be amendment and made accessible to the most in need. Fair and equal access must be restored.

departments.name: Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy

attributes.action: Referendum on ending government's economically costly Ukraine/Russia policies
attributes.background: The government, unless they change their policies, (including ending economically self-defeating sanctions against Russia (causing energy price rises) and sending billions in arms to Ukraine, instead becoming neutral peacemakers), to hold a UK wide referendum on the subject within six months maximum
attributes.additional_details:
The government have intervened on one side in the Ukraine conflict, without any mandate from UK citizens, who have had to suffer massive economic consequences.
These include increased energy, cost of living, interest rate, inflation, unemployment, tax and rates rises, plus strikes, business damage, and reduced government services.
Taxpayers paid £100bn Energy price support and £10bn Ukraine military and other aid to date.
Striving for peace would help end the bloodshed, restore stability and deescalate the world energy, food and refugee situation.

departments.name: Foreign, Commonwealth & Development Office

attributes.action: Stop pensioners paying Income Tax on private pensions
attributes.background:
We were encouraged to take out Private pensions to help in later life. Any increase in State Pension, is taken back by Tax on Private Pension.
, as tax was already paid on wages at source.
attributes.additional_details: This would help Pensioners with the cost of living. As the energy costs rise along with inflation.

attributes.action: Inquiry into Ofgem to determine if it is fit for purpose
attributes.background: An urgent inquiry needs to happen into Ofgem to determine whether they are fit for purpose. This inquiry should consider whether Ofgem is fulfilling its roles and responsibilities as detailed on their About Us page on their website.
attributes.additional_details: The cost of living crisis has got to a point where the average energy bill could go up to £4200 in January 2023. I feel Ofgem have failed in their responsibility of looking after the consumer and not controlling competition in the market, and this must be investigated.

departments.name: Department for Digital, Culture, Media and Sport

attributes.action: Provide interest-free Renewable Energy Assistance Loan during energy crisis.
attributes.background:
A win-win plan that gives immediate and long-term benefits: 
Government to provide interest-free loans to homes for installing renewable energy equipment (solar panel, heat pump, retrofit).
This will reduce monthly utility bills for homes. The savings can repay the loan over 5-7 years.
attributes.additional_details:
A simple plan that benefits everyone:

Households – Immediate cash savings vs paying hefty bills to energy suppliers; less dependency on the grid; no-interest cost on buying expensive equipment. 

Government –  Reduction in inflation; the UK can become energy secure in a few years, also meeting its climate targets 

Suppliers – They can buy excess energy from households at a low cost; they can work with the government in installation, maintenance, billing, and awareness-building.

departments.name: HM Treasury

attributes.action: Significantly increase the Minimum Income Guarantee.
attributes.background: Although the specific rate for MIG is set by Local Authorities for each area around the country it is based on an amount  set by the Department of Health and Social Care in their guidance. This amount needs to be much higher to take into account high inflation and increased energy costs.
attributes.additional_details:
This affects everyone. 

• Only 17% of disabled people were born with their disabilities (Source: Institute for Public Policy Research article Work for disabled people)..

• 11 million disabled people in Britain (Source: Prime Minister’s Strategy Unit)

• It could happen to any of us at anytime

• 2% of the working age population becomes disabled every year, 78% of disabled people acquire their impairment aged 16 or older (Source: Employers' Forum on Disability).

Being disabled costs more.

As it stands the Minimum Income Guarantee will not even cover the increase in energy bills/costs. It is supposed to cover All bills, food, clothing and all normal living costs.

departments.name: Department for Work and Pensions

attributes.action: Urgently review Advisory Electricity Rate (AER) for fully electric company cars
attributes.background: Since the energy price cap increase, domestic electricity costs ~28p/kWh. If a car’s efficiency is 2.8-4.0 miles/kWh, the cost per mile is 7p-10p. The average cost at a public charging point is 44.5p/kWh (~11p-16p per mile). HMRC’s AER is just 5p per mile. HMRC should urgently consider raising this.
attributes.additional_details: This shortfall discourages use of fully electric company cars. The Government should urgently review the current AER. It should also commit to reviewing the AER quarterly in future, as they do for fossil fuels in the Advisory Fuel Rates, and ensure the AER is not based on the lowest available domestic overnight tariff. For example, it would be fairer if the AER were set at the mid-point between the average of the cost of charging on a domestic tariff and on public rapid charging points.

departments.name: HM Treasury

attributes.action: Recall Parliament to consider the Energy Price Cap Increase (Cancellation) Bill
attributes.background: Parliament should be recalled to debate and vote on the Energy Price Cap Increase (Cancellation) Bill, to require Ofgem to maintain the energy price cap at current levels.
attributes.additional_details:
Experts predict that the energy price cap will rise to £4,200+ by January 2023. If correct then this would be a 300% increase vs the price cap of £1,042 in January 2019.
 
Although the Government is providing £400 off of household energy bills from October, and has provided more in direct payments to ‘low income households’, this does not go far enough.
 
More support is urgently needed, especially for working families and taxpayers who have received the lesser amounts of current support level.

departments.name: Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy

attributes.action: Ban outdoor heating and cooling units
attributes.background: Make the use of outdoor heaters and cooling units illegal as they are an unnecessary use of energy and damage the environment. Due to the Covid-19 pandemic, this ban could come into force after this winter. Announcing a ban now should discourage people from buying new heaters now.
attributes.additional_details:
It should help reduce the amount of fossil fuels our country is using, make the UK more likely to meet the requirements of the Paris Agreement (2017), and make the UK a more environmentally-friendly country.
 
If it is too cold to sit outside, wear a coat or sit inside. France have plans to ban outdoor heaters and cooling units after this winter; we should do the same. Other colder countries, like Sweden, manage without outdoor heaters. They simply wear more layers.

departments.name: Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy

attributes.action: Stop new exploration and production licenses for UK Off and Onshore oil and gas.
attributes.background: We would like the UK government to end the exploration and development of new oil and gas fields in the UK and its territories, including the Cambo oil field. The development of new oil and gas fields undermines the UK Government’s commitment to Net-Zero by 2050 and its position as COP26 host.
attributes.additional_details: The Earth is already witnessing the effects of the climate crisis with extreme floods, droughts and wildfires, which, according to the 2021 IPCC report, can only be abated by swift and decisive action. In June 2021, the International Energy Agency recommended that a ban on new oil and gas projects was needed to avoid even worse climate disasters and reach net-zero emissions by 2050. We want the Government and Parliament to take responsibility by putting this recommendation into legislation.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Increase the windfall tax on energy companies and apply it retroactively.
attributes.background: The current windfall tax only applies from when it was introduced and will not apply to the billions in profits that the energy companies have made so far this year. It is also a tiny 25% and should be increased to 50%. Use the funds raised to help those across the UK to cope this winter.
attributes.additional_details: Across the UK millions of people will be facing an impossible choice this winter, will they choose to feed themselves and their children or keep them warm. The current government's plans go nowhere near far enough to help avert this crisis. The amount of windfall tax needs to be increased and applied retroactively for the entirety of 2022. Instead of creating policy with shareholders in mind the government needs to start thinking about those facing poverty this winter.

departments.name: HM Treasury

attributes.action: Help end fuel poverty – make it illegal to charge more for prepaid energy
attributes.background: The Government should support fuel poor households that use prepayment meters by making it illegal for energy providers to charge more for prepaid energy, so customers on prepayment tariffs can access fair rates.
attributes.additional_details: Those struggling to pay for fuel, often use pre-payment meters which can cost up to £378 more per year than households using a credit meter. Research shows that those on prepayment meters are more likely to be low-income or vulnerable households. As a result, they are not able to commit to a credit meter or simply cannot get their credit approved. They, therefore, do not have access to the cheaper credit meter tariffs when they are the people that need these the most.

departments.name: Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy

attributes.action: Stop investing in new nuclear power in the UK
attributes.background: The waste from nuclear energy is a liability for future generations. An accident or terrorist attack at nuclear sites could be catastrophic. New technology means there are green alternatives which we believe are superior to nuclear power. The Government should stop investing in new nuclear power.
attributes.additional_details:
Since new technological developments have improved green power generation, we believe the Government should redirect investment in nuclear energy to wind turbines onshore & off, solar power and tidal powered green energies.
 
It is quicker to produce, still creates jobs if we manufacture in the UK and does not leave a problem for the next generations to dispose of dangerous waste.
 
Some members of the public complain about the look and impact of onshore wind farms in their county, but we believe these are preferable to new nuclear power stations.

departments.name: Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy

attributes.action: Subsidise a 'basic' amount of electricity for households
attributes.background: The Government should fund a subsidised amount of electricity based on Ofgem’s estimate of the average household use and occupancy. This amount would be charged at a rate similar to 2020 prices. Extra usage after this would be at new higher prices.
attributes.additional_details: We cannot avoid the fact that energy has become expensive given world events. But we can choose policies that protect the most vulnerable in society. This proposal is cost neutral (the prices for heavy users will be a bit higher to compensate for the discounted power at the low end) but prevents the poor being proportionately harder hit.

departments.name: Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy

attributes.action: Revoke Development Consent for the Riverside Energy Park in SE London
attributes.background: The Government should revoke the Development Consent Order for the Riverside Energy Park incinerator in South East London, to protect air quality, local wildlife, and the appearance of the area. The incinerator would be located near large populated urban areas.

departments.name: Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy

attributes.action: Remove VAT on domestic energy bills now.
attributes.background: Remove VAT on domestic energy bills.
attributes.additional_details: Rising energy costs mean that households are paying much more VAT. It’s time to introduce an emergency zero VAT rating on domestic energy bills.

attributes.action: Set stricter legal targets for air quality and increase funding for research
attributes.background: The Government’s planned new legal targets for air quality must align with the WHO air quality guideline levels. It should also increase funding for research and development to develop cleaner energy sources and reduce plastic air pollution from tyres. This will also help combat climate change.
attributes.additional_details:
Each year at least 28,000 people in the UK die prematurely because of air pollution, including children. Air pollution has been linked to heart disease, lung disease and cancer, and can exacerbate allergies, skin conditions and pregnancy complications. 
 
Currently we are above the World Health Organisation guideline levels for multiple pollutants. Data from the World Bank shows that 66% of the UK population were exposed to pollution above the WHO standards in 2017.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Reform energy pricing and taxes to better protect lower income households
attributes.background:
We want the Government to legislate to:

• prohibit standing charges
• remove VAT on the first 3000 kwh/year of electricity and 12,000 kwh/year of gas
• increase VAT rate on larger consumers to the standard rate
• subsidise the first 3000 kwh/year of electricity and 12,000 kwh/year of gas
attributes.additional_details:
The rise in energy prices is disproportionately hitting the poorest households in this country and the impact on them is, and will continue to be, devastating.

More people will have to choose between paying for basics like food or keeping their homes warm.

Urgent support is needed to protect those most at risk.

Current action by the government, while welcome, is not targeted and merely 'scratches the surface' of the problems the poorest face.

departments.name: Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy

attributes.action: Require all energy companies to pay interest to customers who are in credit
attributes.background: Require that all companies involved in the supply of domestic gas and electricity pay customers who are in credit interest at the Bank of England rates applicable.
attributes.additional_details:
Millions of customers are or will be in credit owing to the high Direct Debits they are being expected to pay plus the money being paid by the Government.

This is effectively a ‘loan’ to the energy companies upon which the customers see no return.  That money is used by the energy companies to generate more income.

This income should be paid to the customers as interest on the credit.

attributes.action: Require energy suppliers report nation of origin of oil and gas supplies
attributes.background: UK energy suppliers presently have no requirement to reveal the origin of the oil and gas they purchase. As oil and gas purchased from Russia is helping fund the invasion of Ukraine, we believe that transparency is essential.
attributes.additional_details:
Please enact powers requiring such reporting.
 
Requiring energy suppliers to publish the nation of origin of oil and gas supplies will enable consumers to make a personal choice about which energy supplier to use, based on their supply chain.

departments.name: Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy

attributes.action: Introduce legislation to create mechanism for the voters to dissolve Parliament
attributes.background: Create a mechanism whereby the voters, perhaps by means of a petition, can force a General Election without waiting for the next scheduled one.The threshold can be set to discourage vexatious acts, and it could be only valid within a certain window, say not within a year of the last or next election
attributes.additional_details: Our system of elections called when the Prime Minister of the day — supported by Parliament since the FTPA — decides when a General Election can be called has failed. Current events such as the Energy Crisis, the Food Crisis, and the Fuel Crisis, and past events such as the Withdrawal Agreement Crisis prove that. If the government is failing, the People should be able to recall it mid term rather than waiting two or three years for the next scheduled election or the Prime Minister’s whim.

attributes.action: Cancel the energy bill rebate for second homes
attributes.background: I feel it is a very poor use of public money, when there are many more people urgently in need of support. The Government should amend this scheme so people are only eligible for a rebate for their main home.

departments.name: Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy

attributes.action: Keep GMT permenantly in the UK (ie: not to forward clocks for Summer Time).
attributes.background: The benefits of daylight saving time in energy saving is questionable. Adverse effects of seasonal time shift on human have been found. Medical studies have shown a correlation with increased incidences (ie: stroke, depression, IBD).The shift to summer time also have a negative effect on welfare.
attributes.additional_details: From a health and welfare  point of view the Greenwich Mean Time seems more beneficial in the UK, being more in syncronhy with the human biological clock. Therefore the government should consider to keep to the GMT all year around.

departments.name: Cabinet Office

attributes.action: Ban automatic disconnection of people on Pay As You Go Energy Meters
attributes.background: We need the government to ensure there is no Self Disconnecting of energy for the poorest in our society by guaranteeing, that even when they cannot top up the prepay energy meters they will still work. This could be done via a weekly amount put on to the meters or allowing meter to apply debt.
attributes.additional_details: During this inflation we cannot overlook the vulnerable in society. PAYG meters can be cut off and whilst the energy companies are making record profit and raising the average bill to over 4k, they will have to ensure safety of there vulnerable. Write into law that they will not be self disconnected. This could be done by the companies applying a credit to the bills using data they have on average usage, or allowing the meters to run although there are debt owed. we need to do more

departments.name: Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy

attributes.action: Decarbonise UK energy by funding locally-owned renewable micro-grids
attributes.background:
It will cost tens of billions to make electricity production carbon-neutral, but the current national grid is inefficient, with 8-10% of energy lost in distribution or transmission.
 
The Government should instead fund resident-owned renewable energy grids across the country. Power to the people.
attributes.additional_details: We believe the current electricity grid will be both supplemented and superseded by micro-grids, which can provide most of the benefits with fewer downsides - reducing waste, cost and carbon footprint. Micro-grids work locally within the grid system, but can operate independently of the grid if the need or want arises, to power homes, factories, cars or hospitals.

departments.name: Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy

attributes.action: Change the Highway Code to recommend cyclists keep left in most circumstances
attributes.background: The new Rule 72 in the Highway Code should be amended to advise cyclists to keep left at all times when cycling on the road, except when the road narrows sufficiently that it would be dangerous for vehicles to overtake and when approaching a junction or roundabout to turn right.
attributes.additional_details:
The new Rule 72 tells cyclists to "Ride in the centre of your lane, to make yourself as clearly visible as possible", when on quiet roads or streets, (unless being approached from behind by a faster vehicle), in slower-moving traffic, and at the approach to junctions or road narrowings where it would be unsafe for drivers to overtake you.

We believe the new guidance on road positioning could put cyclists and other road users in danger, and will also lead to increased pollution and energy wastage from additional braking and accelerating.

departments.name: Department for Transport

attributes.action: Create a £25 million annual fund to pay for respite breaks for unpaid carers
attributes.background: The Government to create an annual fund of £25m to pay for respite breaks for unpaid carers, many of whom cannot afford to pay for these themselves, and deserve breaks for their caring responsibilities.
attributes.additional_details:
It is estimated that the UK's 13m+ unpaid carers save the treasury around £135bn per year. But many of them are weary and worn out and their caring responsibilities take a toll on their physical and mental health.
 
A mini break, paid for by the Government, could help restore their energy and ability to keep on caring. We believe it's in the Government's own interest that unpaid carers keep on supporting the sick and infirm in the UK but often they need a break to keep going.

departments.name: Department of Health and Social Care

attributes.action: Ban the use of prepayment meters for energy provision.
attributes.background: Currently energy providers dishonestly pretend that poorer customers disconnect from their energy supply voluntarily, they call this "voluntary disconnection", however this is a lie, Nobody ever does such voluntarily it is forced on prepayment customers by the energy providers.
attributes.additional_details: With the ridiculous & unobtainable amounts of money energy providers charge for prepayment use, it's is simply a matter of time before somebody dies in the cold because of so called "voluntary disconnection", it's both dangerous & unsafe to millions & not fair on anyone to pay so much for energy at rates like £10 per day gas & £10 per day electric, the prices are out of control so we need to send a loud message to these energy companies, banning prepayment meters would force them to change.

departments.name: Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy

attributes.action: Set minimum energy efficiency standards for retail fridges
attributes.background:
Supermarket refrigeration uses 1% of the UK's energy.
Inefficient fridge design leads to:
1) wasted energy
2) food spoilage and waste as temperature varies across the cabinet
3) increased plastic packaging to protect food that is kept at the wrong temperature
attributes.additional_details:
The world is under threat from the effects of global warming.

Legislating for improved fridge efficiency should help reduce our carbon footprint and prevent climate change.

Fridge doors may be useful, but can cause problems with hygiene (particularly since the covid-19 pandemic) and for people with mobility issues. Therefore the aim should be improving efficiency whilst maintaining the open design if possible.

I propose legislating for a target of 50% improvement in energy efficiency over the next 10 years.

departments.name: Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy

attributes.action: Require MPs to disclose all shares in energy companies, regardless of size
attributes.background: MPs should be required to disclose any amount of shares in energy companies. These investments could be accruing personal profit as a result of public policy.
attributes.additional_details: If the government's policy concerning the energy hikes results in personal profits from shareholdings, then this would be a direct conflict of interest. Furthermore, any deliberate apathy regarding the price increases and directly profiteering as a by-product would be akin to rigging the system. At the moment, MPs only have to declare holdings which are more than 15% of the share capital or partnership or shares which are valued at more than £70,000.

departments.name: Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy

attributes.action: Reform food, energy, environmental and fishing policy to save the planet
attributes.background: Following the airing of David Attenborough’s programme “Life on our planet”, the Government should take action and implement new laws, restrictions and taxes to: reduce meat production and consumption, switch to 100% renewable energy, stop all deforestation and ban over-fishing.
attributes.additional_details: We are at a critical tipping point. If we do not make changes now, it will be too late. In a matter of less than 10 years, we could see irreversible change that will have devastating impacts for the planet, and our species. We need to start acting on what the experts & natural world is telling and showing us in order to save the planet. We are an influential nation - if we create lasting change, others will follow and we will make the difference desperately needed.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Hold a referendum on the UK meeting net zero much earlier than 2050.
attributes.background: The rising price of fossil fuels is placing an unaffordable burden on the British people. Our reliance on imports of foreign fossil fuels also weakens our national security. We need to ditch our expensive and dangerous reliance on oil, coal and gas far quicker than is currently planned.
attributes.additional_details: The huge rise in energy bills is caused by increasingly expensive fossil fuels. These are responsible for 85% of the rise in bills in the UK according to energy think tank Ember. Green energy saves people money, ends our reliance on gas and oil imported from Britain's enemies and helps limit the flooding and extreme weather caused by climate change and which damages so many communities in Britain. We need to move much faster to achieve these benefits than 2050.

departments.name: Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy

attributes.action: Reduce VAT on Reduced Rate Electricity, gas, heating oil & solid fuel to 0%
attributes.background:
Due to being a member of the EU we were forced to charge VAT on Electricity, gas, heating oil & solid fuel (domestic/residential/charity non-business) of 5%. 
As we are no longer a member of the EU and are out of the transition period we urge the government to reduce this rate to 0%.
attributes.additional_details:
Citizens Advice finding that many people faced an unprecedented income shock. This included the seven million people with no financial savings, the five million self-employed people, many of whom weren’t sure of their eligibility for government support, and 1.5 million people in jobs that didn’t qualify for statutory sick pay.

Assuming energy suppliers pass on all the saving to customers, cutting 5 per cent VAT added on to energy bills should reduce their cost to households by around £60.

departments.name: HM Treasury

attributes.action: Increase requirements and support for renewable energy for domestic property
attributes.background: Legislate that all new buildings should have at least one renewable energy source & increase support to encourage & assist renewable energy to be taken up by existing home owners.
attributes.additional_details: Harnessing the sun and the wind is sustainable energy. It is more difficult to convert and adapt buildings already built and with massive building programs already taking place, very few have solar panels, ground source heat pumps or any other renewable energy. The Government should take steps to address this before it’s too late.

departments.name: Department for Levelling Up, Housing and Communities

attributes.action: Establish a not-for-profit state owned energy provider
attributes.background: Create a Government, state owned energy provider, set low prices to just cover costs. If competitors want to stay in business they must reduce prices to compete or fold. No extra expense for buying back franchises etc. Just compete and help our own people.
attributes.additional_details:
Certain things like utilities should be offered at honest prices to the public throughout the UK. It is simply not fair or decent to let any businesses profiteer on the back of making ordinary people suffer financial hardships when it is not necessary.
A government-run utility company could offer mass employment and honest prices whilst making a modest profit to cover costs. This would also negate the constant tax incentives or payments to help people cope and force honest competition.

departments.name: Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy

attributes.action: Set minimum rate for energy companies to pay people who export excess energy
attributes.background: Under the Smart Export Guarantee, energy companies choose their own tariffs when they buy low-carbon energy from small-scale generators. They then profit by selling this back for the full market rate. The Government should give powers to Ofgem to set a high minimum rate for the SEG.
attributes.additional_details:
We should receive a higher rate than we currently do for the excess energy we export back to the Grid. Consumers are getting ripped off twice: for the energy that they purchase which is now more expensive and for the energy that they export back into the domestic supply which is bought for very little.

Energy companies shouldn't use double standards for the purchase of green energy exported by consumers. They should give something back.

departments.name: Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy

attributes.action: Inquiry into energy companies customer service and Ombudsman’s remit.
attributes.background: Establish an enquiry into energy companies service and the redress that is available to the ordinary customer. At present the power is totally with the energy companies who operate a war of attrition against their customers. The ombudsman’s remit should be changed so they have more powers.
attributes.additional_details: The ordinary customer is receiving appalling service at the hands of energy companies who can bill what they like , when they want and refuse to address that they may be at fault . The ombudsman is not fully fit for the purpose and needs more powers of investigation and more power to award higher compensation levels.

departments.name: Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy
